title: What 7 Key Indicators Are Saying About the Market
description: When almost everything is trading at a high level, a measure of caution is warranted for investors.
content:
[![Morningstar](https://www.morningstar.com/assets/img/morningstar.d826858.svg)](https://www.morningstar.com/)

[\
		Sign In\
	](https://www.morningstar.com/login?destination=https://www.morningstar.com/markets/what-7-key-indicators-are-saying-about-market)

Save $40


Longtime readers might have noticed that I rarely spend much time writing about macroeconomic issues. One of my core beliefs is that it’s almost impossible to predict the direction of interest rates, economic growth, currency movements, or inflation, not to mention how those factors might affect investment performance.

As [Peter Lynch](https://www.morningstar.com/columns/rekenthaler-report/fidelity-magellan-paradox-skill) famously said, “If you spend 13 minutes a year on economics, you’ve wasted 10 minutes.”

That said, it can be helpful to zoom out and take a big-picture view from time to time. The chart below (included in the [Morningstar Markets Observer](https://www.morningstar.com/business/insights/research/markets-observer)) depicts seven key metrics and where each one stands relative to its range over the past 20 years. I like this chart because it packs in so much information; even without reading all the details, you can glean that six of these seven metrics currently stand at pretty high levels relative to their historical ranges. Writ large, that suggests some caution may be warranted.

![A bar graph showing where 7 key market indicators sit relative to their minimum and maximum over the past 20 years.](https://cloudfront-us-east-1.images.arcpublishing.com/morningstar/RFHCD7QGXBBKVJ57FWQ427OUKI.png)

Source: Morningstar Direct, Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, and National Association of Realtors. Minimums and maximums are for the period from Jan. 1, 2006 through Dec. 31, 2025.

## Gold

**Current level:** Very high.

**What it means:** Gold has been on a tear, but be wary of chasing performance.
